page.title: 09Trowlesworthy local history1
page.content: ANTIQUITIES A. Bronze Age remains are scattered on either side of the Plm valley. They include numerous hut circles, some in groups surrounded by pounds.Also a number of cairns, two stone rows, a standing stone and a large stone circle. B.Ancient reeves or boundary banks are of unknown period but often occur near Bronze Age settlements. C.A re-erected way cross by the side of the road is one of a large number erected in medieval times to mark routes across the moor, particularly linking monastries. D.Stone quarrying used to take place at Trowlesworthy Tor where the pink granite was especially desirable. E. The vermin trap on Legis Tor is a reminder of when rabbits were a valuable food source.
